text: Hi! I just joined this group and excited for tips on traveling to Italy with 3 teenage girls next summer for 8-9 days. Any unique things to do with them around Rome, Venice, Cinque Terre or somewhere on the coast (Positano, Naples)? I’m wondering if Tuscany is a big draw for teen girls ovet the cities listed above. I’ve seen all the big cities in Italy so I’m ok not hitting all the classics and doing a couple of kid focused things).

comments.comment_text: 1st decide if it's 8 or 9 days, without arriving and departing included in that,2nd that's too many places for 9 days. 3d, since your girls are teens and I'm sure on the internet often, have them start looking at areas of interest to not only get involved and excited but also learn about the places you're going to. You could all talk about each place every couple of weeks or so and decide from the interests you all have. Since you all have never been, Rome and Florence are a good start. 5 days in Rome with a day trip to Pompeii, 4 in Florence.
Don't do too much!!!! Take time in each place.

https: //
wyldfamilytravel . com /
italy-with-teena
gers/

There aren’t many kid focused activities over here. Plus if they’re in their teen years they gonna be able to enjoy the adult attractions. We bring children to museums here since they’re 6/7 years old
I would do Sorrento area. You have the ferries to go to Capri. Amalfi. Ischia for the hot pools. Probably more into than churches for them.
They would get a kick out of O’Parrucchiano dine in a lemon grove in Sorrento
If you want a boat tour contact Capitano Ago. They were Awesome. We had a bit too much fun.
Our girls (ages 15, 17) loved Tuscany. Siena has some amazing stores and I think they both enjoyed the slower pace that came with getting out of Florence.

text: Is it better, more affordable, to stay in La Spezia and do day trips to the 5 villages of Cinque Terre?

comments.comment_text: I’m interested to know where is best to stay also. So confusing
We did this in May and loved it!
I’ve never stayed in La Spezia, but can heartily recommend Levanto, which is a few kilometers north of the Cinque Terre. Super easy access to all five villages, but a charming town itself.
We stayed in Riomaggiore and loved it.
We stayed in La Spezia for 4 nights. Loved the area. Easy access to the train station and a wonderful selection of restaurants as well

We stayed in Riomaggiore at a charming b&b. IL Bo Ma. Very good b&b at a reasonable price. Close to the train station and in the centre of the town with shops and restaurants nearby.Our Italian host was very helpful and spoke perfect English.Contine
ntal breakfast was placed at our door every morning. We were able to make fresh coffee every day with an espresso machine that was provided for us and fridge was stocked with water and yogurt.We bought a 24 hour train pass from the train station in Riomaggiore that allowed us to travel all day visiting all 5 villages. Really enjoyed our stay there! It is a beautiful and charming place!
Stay in Marina di Massa. Hotels. Cost you a third of hotels in Pisa of Florence. Boat leave jetty very morning from 10 am that goes to cinque terra. 20euros

I'm currently staying in Vernazza and it's great. I've visited the other villages, and would probably have liked Monterosso for the beach/sun lounges. Vernazza has a tiny beach you can lay at. Riomaggiore and Manarola have boat ramps, so not ideal for swimming as far as I could tell. I didn't visit Cornigila as I've heard there's hundreds of steps to climb from the train station, and after doing the Vernazza to Monterosso hike yesterday my legs were too tired for that today. I'm glad I chose Vernazza to stay at, it's really close to the train station (Riomaggoire and Manarola had long tunnel walkways to wheel your luggage through - they also seemed a bit quiter/not as much atmosphere maybe?). I can't comment on staying at La Spezia, as i always wanted to experience one of the towns, in the evening once the crowds are gone. Well worth it! The trains get incredibly packed, so be prepared for that. Best time to go is early morning, then you'll just have to fight the crowds later in the day heading back.
Yes, lots cheaper. Also, look at Levanto.

In 2019, my kids and I stayed (extended our trip after my husband went home) in La Spezia right near the train station. We were only in the area for two nights. We would jump on the train and explore Monterosso, Vernazza, and Manarola. What I liked about it was I could run to the large grocery store and cook meals at the AIRBNB. We would venture out in the am, come home and relax, have dinner, and then head back to the 5 Villages. I am not sure about the other villages, but I didn't see any large markets where you could obtain food and cook at home. We were on a budget so this worked out for us and I enjoyed heading back in the evenings when the crowds died down. With that said, we are heading back next summer and I splurged and got a place in Monterosso in Old Town (we really want to hike this time since our kids). So, if you stay in La Spezia, I would stay right near the train station so you can jump on the train and you are not spending a lot of time walking back and forth from the station.

text: Is there more than one train station? Will be going from Rome to Florence.

comments.comment_text: Florence Santa Maria novella for the main station x
Take the high speed train from Roma Termini to Firenze Santa Maria Novella. Those are the main stations.
Each has one main, end of the line, station.

Hi, just look up on www.trainline.c
om, it has all the companies and timetables… it’s like $5 extra per ticket but their website is easier to understand
Yes
There are the main stations, but of course how the train is going to the city, there are stations
What train is best to use from Rome to Amalfi Coast?
Roma termini is huge. You will find a lot of trains that will take you to Florence.

Main stations served by most high speed trains: Roma Termini (short: Roma T.), Firenze Santa Maria Novella (short: Firenze S.M.N.)

Other stations also served by high speed trains (but fewer) or intercity trains: Roma Tiburtina, Roma Ostiense, Firenze Campo di Marte.

text:
Hi all, apologies if this is a silly question. I have problem feet and need really good arch support. I have dressy leather flop flops that I was planning on taking with me, but I read some museums and restaurants won't let me in, and in general flip flops are only worn to the beach. Is this really the case?
So far I can't find sandals that I would be able to walk all day in unfortunately :(
Thank you!

comments.comment_text: I just returned from Italy and no one was wearing flip flops.

Sort of true. Basilica is very holy . Yes flip l flop are beach attire. Try a Vionic brand sandal. They have an arch support . Wear before you go on holiday. A dressy Birkenstock? Try Nordstrom . All big towns in Europe lots of walking . Off the main tourist attraction expert cobblestone. Try a clean white sneaker ( if Trinny Woodall can do this with a Prada dress so can we. Good luck
Maybe get some orthotics made that suit your feet. Then buy shoes the orthotics will fit into.
Dressy leather flip flops should be fine. Dollar tree flip flops would be frowned upon
Taos sandles... lots of support. I wore them everywhere.

I found Hokas and I’m never going back! I have hammer toes on both feet, a missing toe on my left foot, a fallen arch and Diabetic Charkot foot on my right foot, and must wear expensive custom orthotics in all shoes. Both regular and wide width Hokas work. I wore the same pair every day on my recent trip to Greece & the islands. Never felt more support or comfort than in my Hokas. I’m a believer!
Try Vionics; the best!
I have Morton's Neuroma and had Bunion surgery. I need a good arch support as well. I just bought Baretraps sandals Jaxen Sandal. They are so comfortable.
I have very high arches. Skechers arch fit sneakers were fantastic and I wore them everywhere. Oerfectly acceptable at all places.

Regardless of foot issues remember Italy is full of cobblestones & stairs! Are your flip flops going to be safe if it’s raining? Will they support your ankle if you jar it on uneven ground? Are you happy to carry bags wearing thongs? Oops flip flops 🩴🩴. Save them for the beach (which is often uneven pebbles too) & wear runners, your feet will thank you

People fall all the time in Europe because of the cobblestones and uneven pavement and steep stone stairways. Flip flops can be dangerous as they do not give enough support to your feet and ankles. I like Teva sandals that stay strapped to my feet.
Wear them and if staff stops you, explain your special needs to them and more likely than not, they’ll let you through. 💕💕💕
Flip flops are only used to go to the beach

Please try and wear sneakers if you can. I have bad feet and made the mistake of touring Spain in what I thought was going to be a good supportive pair of sandals and it was excruciatingly painful, the cobblestones make it worse. I ended up buying sneakers before we arrived in Italy and I am soooooo glad I did as the streets were worse there
Sketchers have a sale on at present. Lots of people swear by them and the comfort. Nurses wear them.

We were in Europe for a month and I wore my Yellow Box flip flops every single day!!
I did read an article that said that’s how they know that you’re an American!! 🤣
Literally no one cares what you wear on your feet. Wear what you want
Check with New Balance. They have trainers for different type of feet and walk, with various widths too.

We were in Italy in May and everyone was wearing white sneakers even with dresses. Get a pair with really good arch supports like Brooks or On clo￼udflyers. If you’re wearing sandals, try Bzees- they have excellent arch support for people who have high arches. Good luck and enjoy!

I’d be afraid to wear flip flops on all those uneven pavers/
cobblestones! Try NAOT or Finn Comfort sandals. I also have problem feet and these work for me. Also the footbed is removable so a good shoe repair place can add additional arch support to the underside of the footbed if needed.
Check to see if your flip flop brand make any regular sandals & if they do, give them a try rather than the flip flops. My podiatrist & foot surgeon told me to never wear flip flops.
Try Vionic brand or Hokas
I wear Tevas. Not sure if you've tried them. Never flipflops.
Wear sneakers

Try Abeo brand, find them and others for high arches at:
thewalkingcompa
ny.com

If you cant afford or dont have time to get proper orthotics look for something like Superfeet an orthotic type insert and buy shoes that let you insert them. In italy you can find shops that sell comfortable orthopedic type shoes.

You don't want to walk on cobblestone streets in flip-flops. Get some good leather supportive walking shoes. I have walked all over Europe in my SAS walking shoes. Not stylish, but seeing the young girls in the equivalent of combat boots with skirts, I don't think they look bad ;)
I would never wear flip flops there. Good tennis shoes all the way

I was in Italy in may and I wore Clark’s cloud steppers Sandal/ flip flop and I wore them everywhere and no issues.. I also have issues with my feet but they are great and comfortable.. we also did a lot of walking, best I found so far

I also have issues with my feet, I bought a pair of Hoka shoes and wore them every day for 5 weeks, a lifesaver and never had a problem with my feet, walked at least 15000 steps each day and sometimes more, great for cobblestone streets! Best $180 I ever spent on shoes.
Aetrex is excellent for arch support! They have inserts, sandals and tennies - I swear by them. Hokas for extra cushion and you can get an Aetrex insert if needed!

I have never had an issue after countless trips. I wear flip-flops in the evening because I have really narrow feet and can never find sandals to fit. And then I wear sneakers during the day when we’re walking.
They can deny you entry- or you might slip by. Just be prepared.

I just has foot reconstruction surgery in Dec. Ì brought my Hokas during the day and my Vionex for night life. TIP OF THE DAY!!! I got break away ice packs from Amazon for swelling at night. It wasn’t the best, but it was better than nothing.

I just did 30,000 steps a day in Paris with my problem feet wearing Fit Flop sandals with a back strap. They have lots of arch support. (This sounds like an ad but I swear I have no connection to the company. 🙂 )

Check out an Ecco store. If you need firmer arch supports, they sell insoles that you can simply swap out in your shoes. You can even travel with both pairs of insoles if you want to fool your feet into thinking that you’re wearing different shoes.
Vionics are the best, in my opinion. They are now making dressier shoes with awesome arch support. I really love their flip flops though.
Birkenstocks hands down best for my awful feet !
I've had good luck with Merrell's sandals which have very good arch support.
Keen sandals! Great all-around sandals for all-day wear. Don't know if there is a pair that would be dressy enough for what you are looking for. More sporty.
Check out cushionaire sandals.
Hokas are the bomb

Flip-flops in Italy? You’ll fall flat on your face on the cobblestone lol! Save them for the beach or just out￼ to eat but not for walking … get a pair of good walking sneakers, I know I don’t like them either, but it’ll save you !!!
The Dr. Scholl’s tennis shoes are great and so are Sofft sandals. I wore those while in Italy. Walked 1000’s of steps and never had sore feet.

I have major feet issues including a torn plantar fasciitis & torn joint. I did NOT take flip flops. I found a pair of￼ tevas that have multi colors. They worked awesome! My feet didn’t hurt when I wore them through Rome. Tuscany, & Florence.

I went to a store that sold walking shoes and bought a good pair of leather shoes that provided arch support and were comfortable all day. You do not want to wear open toed shoes in public with all the disgusting germs etc
Vionic sandals are great for poor feet…

No restaurant or museum (that I know of) is going to deny you entry if you are wearing flip flops. I wear Vionics and can walk for miles in them. They are not beachwear and I have several styles. (I just ordered 3 new pair…don’t tell my husband. Lol). You will be fine.
I need that too..

I've had insane foot issues over the last few years, and the last few times I've gone to Europe I have lived in Oofos flip flops because of them. You can take a real pair of something cute to change into for dinner if you feel the need.
Look into Orthofeet sandals.
I love the Dansko Tanya sandals- great arch support and I can walk in them all day.
I have traveled in Birkenstock sandals all over Italy and never had any problems in museums or restaurants
Try NAOT SANDALS

As someone who used to manage a podiatrist office he said 50 percent of people’s foot problems are because of wearing poor foot wear ie flip flops.
I would try some sneakers. All of the walking you will be doing your feet will thank you. Some supportive nice sandals for dinner perhaps.
Skechers sandals
No one will look at your feet.. Wear what ever works for you as there is lots of walking.
I wore flip flops without any issues
nobody cares about your shoes, unless you go to fancy restaurants or clubs.

text: Question for those of you who have visited wineries in Tuscany. Are they kid friendly? I have a very well behaved 13 year old who I would be traveling with.

comments.comment_text: All of Italy is kid friendly. We saw kids on our winery tours. I think the more important question is if he will like it or be bored.

Normally they are kids friendly, maybe ask before if there is some issue (maybe for insurance reasons entering wine cellars) but I highly doubt it.
He probably will also be able to sip something from your glasses, so he can start wine appreciation the Italian way 😁

Absolutely! They even let my daughter(15) have a smaller tasting. We don’t let her drink at home but they sample at very young ages there. This one was beautiful and they did a wine pairing with lunch so the kids didn’t get bored! https://
www.altieroinchi
anti.it/en/
tastings/
Curious what wineries you were considering? We will be traveling in November with 2 teenage kids and we’re curious too!
They are not age crazy like we are. Enjoy. Order what you like and have them ship it to the US.
Just got back and we had a 19 year old 2 16 year old and a 14 year old. It was all good
I took mine on one
Everywhere we have been it Italy has been kid friendly!
We brought our kids! Only issue is the kids might be bored.
We’ve taken little kids and they kind of enjoyed it. During the tasting part, they brought the kids a little charcuterie plate and some juice.
My kids were younger and sometimes offered a taste. He’ll be fine. The tours can be educational and entertaining too.
I would call and inquire .
I’m a native Californian. My parents took my brother and I along when they went wine tasting in the 70s when I was that age. The information is interesting - and if there’s a wine cave, it’s a plus.

I found all of Europe and even Morocco to be very kid/family friendly. Every airport had family lines, and it seemed every place we went had kids and families everywhere. This includes some “fancy” places for dinner in Positano and Venice, tours that I would consider more for “adults”, etc. Acting inconvenienced by children seems to be very American 😂
Italy LOVES kids,
Shouldn't be a problem!
Our family of 5 loved it. Kids 13, 16, 21
He’ll love it
Thanks everyone!
Very kid friendly & will even ask you if it is ok to offer wine to them.
It's Italy 🇮🇹. Adatto ai bambini 🥰

The one we did (with our 4 kids, ages 6 up to 15), they said all the kids could taste the wine because they’re over 4! We didn’t take up the offer, much to the kids disappointment,
but they had an absolute ball, they loved it & were very welcome!
We love kids in Italy :)
Yes 🙌
They have shorter wine tasting ones. Plus if you google wine tasting/farm with animal petting zoo is also good for smaller children so parents can seat and animal farm was right there.
Yes

text:
Hi! Can I have suggestions on how much time is needed in each of these places please? Don’t want to feel like we are just traveling the whole time.
Milan, Venice, Tuscany area, Rome, Sicily?
Thank you.

comments.comment_text: Milan 2 nights, Venice 3 nights, Tuscany 5-6 nights (including a trip to Florence), Rome 4-5 nights, Sicily 7 nights minimum.

It depends on what, and how much, you want to see... I've been going to Venice at least once a month all my life, and there's still lots to see. Ditto for Rome.
Personally, I'd much rather take it easy and see well one or two major sites than try to cram everything in 1 day.
I would say at least a year to see all of it..🤔
Rome no more than few days (2-3), Tuscany depends on your plans for 4-5 days
Following
A lifetime ! (But in the alternative)I would say Milan - 2 nights; Tuscany 6-7 nights; Rome 4 nights; Sicily 7-10 nights.

Milan 1 for sights, more for high-end shopping if that appeals to you. Venice minimum 2 full days and nights. Tuscany 2 for Florence and 2-3 for Siena, Lucca, San Gimignano. Rome 4 days. Sicily 5-6. Of course, you could spend more in all of them.
We did a tour of Sicily for 11 days, which was amazing, but there's still much we didn't get to see!

You’ll just scratch the surface of each to attempt all, given a normal holiday timeframe. At the very least, drop Sicily and try to do it alone in the future. I spent 11 days there last year and only tried to see the western half, it was too rushed for just half of it.
Would break trip up into 2 visits: North and South. Don’t spread yourself thin, best experiences come from lingering, savoring and immersing oneself.

I would suggest 3-4 days in each city… longer for Rome & Tuscany. Gather you’re staying at airbnbs’s? Marriott hotel points users get the 5th night free when booking with points.. always recommend that if you’re a Marriott person.
3 nights in Rome is perfect. Stay in Lucca for a week and explore Tuscany including Florence. 3 nights in Venice.

Great question. Travelling can drain our energy, and create needless stress. Couple of things: You've mention 3 cities, and 2 regions. Tuscany is vast, and Sicily even more vast, geographically.

You have to decide what you want out of the 2 regions, and narrow down where you will focus your stay. I'd suggest watching some youtube videos from well rated sources.

As for the cities - Milan, Venice and Rome, honestly, for me a week in each would not be enough. I recently spent 3 days in Venice and later on, a week in Milan, and I really wish I had done a full week in Venice, and 10 days in Milan.

I get that folks are strapped for time, but how I pulled off longer stays, was to sacrifice other short term travel I might have once done at home. Haven't had a winter vacation in about 8 years (as a Canadian "snowbird" that really IS a sacrifice. LOL). But at the end of the day, rushing through Italy at breakneck speed ticking stuff off of a "must do" list, just does not work for me. It is the opposite of what the lifestyle in Italy is about.
Tuscany only could take 2 weeks if you are into hiking and swimming besides art and history.
I’ve kind of felt that…I think in future I will do two days minimum each place, one day to explore, one day of down time. 👌🏻
I would say 12-16 months each location just a guess. I’ll let you know in 3 weeks when we get there for the first time !!! Wooo Hooo !!

It really depends on what you want to see and do in each location. And on your individual
Interests and travel style.

For me I’d break it down approximately like this

Milan 2 full days.
Venice 4 full days
Rome 5 full days. Or more
Tuscany is a whole area with countless cities and towns. So maybe a full week.
Sicily. Also a full week.

Naturally even more time in each place would be better.

Prosecco!! You can get Prosecco instead of water if you’d like. Sometimes it comes with a meal. Definitely snacks

text: Hi we are in Venice right now -any recommendations for a cevchitti tour and also a seafood restaurant preferably water fee for our 40 th anniversary dinner?

Hi!
I’m hoping to get some help with Lake Como. We are there for two nights and hope to do a lake tour. Just wanting to know what you found is great and affordable. Or will you see most things on the Ferry?
Also are water taxis available and affordable?
Thank you, just trying to work out our itinerary.
🥳🙏

comments.comment_text: You can’t see everything from the ferries, have to get off in each town. What mode of transport are you using to get there? If train, I would go to Varenna and stay there, short ferry ride to Bellagio and Mennaggio, all very quaint.

We did this last month a little pricy but well worth it! you can save a bit if you drive yourself but the boat you’ll get is only 40 hp and you dont have any guide. The ferries are a nightmare the lines to buy a tickets are so long and your supposed to be able to buy online but when your in their website it keeps saying nothing is available, W ended up getting in line in Como ticket office at 8am thinking were early finding there was a long line already ended up being in line close to 2 hours finally catching the ferry to Bellagio from como at 10 and arrived in bellagio close to noon , pretty much wasted half of our day, I heard water taxis are pretty expensive but i have not confirmed this and if you travel by bus can take you longer due to traffic and one local told me if there happens to be an accident while your on your way to any town you’ll be stuck in traffic for hours. We stayed in Como for 3 days but if we have to do it all over again it would have been a lot better to just stay In bellagio and have that as your base to visit other towns in lake como.

Getting around como is freaking miserable. We absolutely loved being there, but public transport was extremely unpredictable and unreliable. Busses running late, not way to know if they'll stop where they say they will or when, taxis are few and far between and insanely expensive, so much so that it's hard to even get to the next town over. We decided if we were to ever go back we would absolutely need to rent a car. Every where else we went in Italy was no problem, and our issues were most certainly nothing to do with poor planning.
Following

I stayed in Varenna and caught the ferry to Bellagio & Menaggio, which was easy. I left at 9am so it wasn’t too busy yet. However coming back from Menaggio at 1pm it was a long line in the hot sun to buy tickets. I like the heat, so it didn’t bother me. However packing a small umbrella might be a good idea.
No idea about private charters. As a solo traveller it would’ve been way over my budget.

To take the fast ferry, you must get in line in the morning around 7:30. You cannot buy a return ticket until you arrive at your destination. If you are going from Como to Bellagio, as soon as you arrive, go buy your return tickets. If you’re going from Como to Varenna, and are on a midday ferry, you have a slim chance of getting return tickets. That is because the people that got off in Bellagio are buying them before you ever get to Varenna. If you’re on an early ferry, you’ll likely get tickets. That leaves the bus, the train (from Varenna) the slow ferry. None are great options. If you’re in Bellagio and are planning to take the bus back to Como at around 5:00, prepare for a battle at the bus stop. There will be a mob of 100 people trying to get on the bus.
f
Carrie Swanson
Following
Callum Audet

I was there a month ago, we didn’t have a car. We stayed in Varenna and ferry to Bellagio and Menaggio were about 20 mins, always got on both ways and always bought a return ticket! All places are absolutely wonderful!
We also had a ‘middle of the lake tour’ 50€ each for an hour but we’ll worth it, the guide took you to all the famous villas and hotels to see them from the lake! This is the company and he’s based in Varenna by some restaurants, opposite side to the port but only 10 min walk.
https://
taxiboatvarenna.
com/
We are going June 2024 and have just booked B&B como... hopefully ok !

We spent 4nts in Bellagio late June. The ferry situation from Comp to anywhere is ridiculous, being unable to buy return tickets, but it is what it is. After maybe 1.5hr wait in the sun we got on a slow ferry in the end, as we weren’t in a hurry, and it was a good way to check out which towns we wanted to visit in the coming days! We took a ferry to Menaggio and Barenna one day, it was simple (could buy return tickets) and beautiful. We took the bus to Como and it was super easy and a different perspective of the lake. Coming back to Bellagio around 6pm was busy, but still do-able.

We stayed in Lezzeno on lake Como 2 weeks ago for 6 nights. It’s just outside of Bellagio. Honestly the ferries were frustrating and super busy. We ditched that idea and twice rented a boat for private use. You do not need a licence and we had SO much fun. We switched off in quiet places and had a swim in the lake. Obviously someone always stays on the boat. You see SO much more and can take your time. Boat rentals are very flexible, anything from 1h to all day. We found it much more enjoyable. The ferries rush from one place to the next and when they’re full you don’t see anything.
Boat rental was 150€ for 2 hours and 210€ for 3 hours. Sounds expensive, but we thought it worth it. We even docked at Lenno and went to buy Gelato while my husband stayed with the boat. Great fun.
Erin McDonald
Just take the ferry. It’s like a hop on hop off bus. Get off at towns you want to see
Following

We just got back from staying in Bellagio for 3 nights- we rented a car and while the drive was a very narrow at times, I couldn’t imagine relying on public transit. Ferry situation was very busy. Never ventured to como but took it Bellagio to Varenna leaving at 10AM and returning at 1pm and it was okay. Lines starting to build tho. We rented a boat with a private driver for 2 hours for 600$ but was an amazing experience. Friday and Saturday much busier than Sunday to Monday.

I'm in Menaggio right now with my daughter and my advice is this. Leave the ferries out of it as much as possible. We are only here for two nights, and I'd heard Bellagio is so beautiful that this morning we went to do a short trip across for the morning. It was so crowded that I let it go and decided to stay and explore Menaggio. Great decision! I think every town is stunningly beautiful and it's great to pick one and enjoy it thoroughly if you don't have much time. I can ride a boat on a lake anywhere, but exploring the back alleys at a leisurely pace, strolling through the piazzas or along the shore with gelato, these are the things to do in the precious short time spent at Lake Como. I guess if you can afford a private boat tour that would be the way to go, but even then I think you wouldn't have enough time in each place and would still be better off enjoying one town. You can't see everything in a two night stay so ENJOY one place.
Where are you staying? The train runs the length of the east side, then you can catch the ferries. You must visit Varenna and Villa Monastero. Much preferred to Bellagio.

I think it depends on the time of year you are there. We stayed in Varenna for 2 nights in early May. We traveled to Varenna by train from Milan, about 1 hour. Loved Varenna. We took the ferry to Bellagio one day with no issues and no long lines. We took a water taxi tour from Varenna to Villa del Balbianello. The price included a tour of the Villa. It was beautiful. The water taxi drove by and pointed out other sites along the way. There is more shopping in Bellagio than Varenna but I preferred Varenna. Very quaint. If you go there have a meal at Al Prato, reserve early.

text:
Hi, Im new here!
Ive seen a few posts re esim for Italy and i have a specific question but I seem to be unable to comment on the posts Ive seen on this subject.
So here goes.
I am looking at using airalo esim and I want to know if I can use this with my existing Australian number… or do I get a number attached to this sim. I know ai am able toआणखी reatain my aussie number while using another esim but just want to know if airalo esim provides another number. I have done lots of research and cannot find the answer anywhere. Ideally seeking answers from Aussies who have used airalo in Italy/Europe.
Thank you !!

comments.comment_text: Just came back from 5 weeks holiday and we used Holafly and it was the best. My son is over there now and also using it.

I used it and was very happy with the price and service. But no phone number as Karen above notes. Just data, no voice no texting.
FB Messenger, what's app, signal, etc etc worked fine.

I don’t think you can keep your own number unless you use your provider. A lot of esims only provide data. If you want calls, I believe you get a new number - probably from a European country. We have purchased a sim for calls and data in EU. Let me know if you want more info. Also from Oz.
I am from Oz and used Airalo, it is data only if you turn on your Aussie SIM depending on your plan you will get charged OS roaming costs if it is enabled

We just recently returned and used sims direct which is Aussie owned. You order a SIM card before leaving and swap out with your normal SIM card on arrival. Obviously you need to have an unlocked phone. This gives you a new number but you can retain your normal No on WhatsApp which makes things easier for bookings you may have. We got the $35 one as we went to Italy and the UK which lasts a month. We can definitely recommend Sims Direct.
We paid for one month internally with our phone company. $100 unlimited data,texting and 250 mints calling

I was very confused for ages too but here is my simple understanding of how an esim works.
1. Put your phone on air plane mode
2. Then go somewhere where you get free wifi, like McDonald’s.
3. You can now use your phone to do anything with data enabled. Ie
Messenger, FaceTime and what’s app calls,
using your phone number and send/receive blue sms, use google maps, search the web etc.
5. But you can’t make normal phone calls as your phone is on airplane mode.
6. So your esim is the McDonald’s wifi.
I hope this helps.
Can’t you make calls through iMessage which uses data? Not sure how to do it though
Thank you to all who replied, makes sense now!

Airalo is data only. Leave your primary sim active so you can receive texts and calls. Turn data roaming off on your primary sim. But don’t answer calls or reply to texts with your primary sim, use your eSIM Data for calls and messages etc. I’ve used it a lot so feel free to reach out if you have any questions. ☺️

Why are you bothering.... you just pay a bit extra to your telecommunicati
ons provider and have roaming....

You could just turn on international roaming! I know Vodafone does it for $5 per day. You can switch it off for the days when you don't plan to make or receive calls and just use your phone in airplane mode with WiFi on. Most hotels and Airbnb will have free WiFi.
Hola regrese hace dos semanas de Europa y contraté aíralo por un mes . Seguí con mi mismo número sin ningún problema y me funcionó muy bien te lo recomiendo. 👍

Hi. I’m from Australia and used Airalo esim while in Italy, as did my son. We bought the 30 day mamma Mia package and it was brilliant and easy to use. You do not get a number with the esim. We used WhatsApp to make calls as that’s what everyone in Italy uses. Buy the esim and download it to your phone before you leave, and when you arrive in Italy, turn the data off on your exiting number and turn it on for esim. You do this through settings-mobile
-then select the sim.

i've set up an unlimited EU Esim - Maya Mobile plan. Keep your own number, you are able to also hotspot for others & you can tether your laptop. I'm travelling through Europe for 5 weeks & will be working during that time.
Helen Wake @ $10 a day - far too expensive

Just back from Italy & used Airolo. Great for data only - calls on whatsapp or messenger- I've attached screenshot of where you need to make sure you turn off your home sim, & turn on the esim. Because you leave your physical sim in the phone, & you have International roaming, you can still receive text messages & phone calls. If you answer phone or send text messages, it will trigger the daily $10 charge. 2 important things to note:
1. Activating a day pass works on Australian Eastern Time Zone. So if you activate it at 3pm in Italy & then again at 5pm, you will be charged $20 😡
2. Make sure you turn off your message bank - even if you don't answer a call, if it diverts to message bank, you will be charged the $10 daily fee 😡
Simonetta Seri
We used Amaysim and it was fantastic! We kept our own number. The only issue is that you need to be with amaysim in Australia and we just added$70 roaming pack . We were away for over 2 months

Australian here- Yes you can. Get the regional Esim and you have greater flexibility. It’s data only but WhatsApp and messenger as well as internet are accessible pretty much everywhere. We used it in Europe including Italy in May and I’m using my Asian Esim now to respond to you from Vietnam
Apparently you keep your own number but turn your phone to airplane mode then switch your data to AloSim while abroad

Telstra is $10 a day when you use it, but you have to watch the time and work it out as it’s AEST.
Perth is 6 hours ahead of Europe,the East Coast 4 hours.
I turn mine on every few days to call home and check messages etc…
In between those days I just use the wifi and use WhatsApp or messenger.

I used Holafly. I am US based, apparently they gave me an Australian number but I don’t know what it is! So no you can’t use for 2 step verification. I just What’s App’d my son to give me a verification code I put in his number 😂
You can dowload flyesim app and still using your local number
Most affordable one is flyesim app

text:
Hello! Arrived yesterday. This group has been helpful. Lemme return your kindness by sharing a few things I realised:

1. Leonardo express is so convenient when you want to get to Termini Station from FCO. You can just buy your ticket there (15 euros only) and after 32 min, you are at the station. Do this when your hotel is near the station. Extremely easy, no need to book in advance.

2. I did use the subway as suggested by rome2rio, it took me a while to find it but it is manageable ( I am a solo traveler and since I traveled with just a carry-on.. I was able to navigate easily. Many have warned us about pickpocketers, just be extra vigilant and you will be fine) I do not mean to discount the stories of those who have lost their essentials and I am sorry for such experiences you had. All I wanna say is, if you choose to take public transportation, be mindful of your surroundings all the time.

3. After the subway was the plot twist, I still had to get an uber to find my way to the hotel. I am staying at TH Roma Carpegnale hotel which is not that far from the station. It took me almost an hour to find one. Uber works fine but it depends on where you are. They are pretty particular with the pick up point so it is not like you will just type where u are and they will find you. On the contrary, they will let u know where and u must find it.

4. Having said those, while I tried to be economical by using the train and subway, then uber- I computed and realised it is a lot better if I just took a taxi from the airport (esp my hotel is not near Termini Station) I could have saved more (time and money)

5. Shoes are always a topic in this group, I agree, wear comfortable ones but once here, you will find so many women wearing heels and sandals and they are just okay. (Again, u know yourself better-no one will judge u if u did not wear your rubber shoes)

6. I used the e-sim Airalo and it works perfectly.
7. Cards are accepted pretty much everywhere. no need to carry lots of cash (just enough to tip)
8. I did not have everything planned and ate at wherever looks authentic Italian restaurant whenever I got hungry. Part of the joy for me.
9. weather is hot but not unbearable 🙂
10. Let me conclude by saying, do not be afraid to “Rome” around- you may be lost but it is all worth it. God bless you all!

But you are right - they will give you a pick up point nearby and we found we had to find that before accepting. Worth every penny over walking in 98’F. We had a pickpocket experience and again, it was clear as we tried to get on the metro, the thieves were trying to make our entrance tricky to embark. So my husband ( with wallet in pocket) was being jolted by 2 ladies whilst my son and I struggled to get on- on a quiet carriage but they were half blocking the doors. By the time I got on, I could see the distraction technique, told my husband to move away. In a split second they had taken his wallet. Luckily doors were closed, he grabbed the thief’s shoulder shouting where’s the wallet, I grabbed the bag of her accomplice who pointed at the floor- she had just dropped it so we got it back. You are right, they are very clever and it was because of this FB group, I recognised the diversion. Techniques people had spoken about. After that, he just used his Apple Pay and I gad been using cross body bag with hand on it at all times. 2 restaurant tips - Emma and Tonnarello. We were staying kn a Trastevere which also had a handy CONAD supermarket in the OVS dept store. Just 20min walk from Pantheon. Taxi rank across the road in Via Di Trastevere.

text: Am I missing a major food rule in Italy? Sitting at a restaurant we asked for olive oil for our bread and the waiter seemed really upset that we asked. He then proceeded to take our plates away and kept say ‘non possibile’ like 5 times. Then 2 minutes later came back ok here is the olive oil. I’m really confused what happened and what we did wrong. Can someone fill me in?

comments.comment_text: Only tourists did it
only tourists can ask something like that.
Oh wow, I’m intrigued to hear responses as to why also 🤨

Un italiano non mette l'olio sul pane al ristorante..com
unque non mi sembra così sconvolgente,c'
è di peggio,tipo il cappuccino con la pasta.
Doesn’t matter if tourist ask, a paying customer is a paying customer and seems like tourists support business and should be treated better
My friend from Italy said that dipping bread in olive oil is an American thing. Not a normal practice in Italy.
Places I went had olive oil and balsamic on the tables… 🤷🏼‍♀️
Just a guess. He probably felt insulted. They take great pride being a server and they move at a relaxing pace. 🤷🏼‍♀️
My understanding is that the bread they give you is for mopping up sauces etc from your food and that asking for oil/butter is very much an American/uk thing.

We had half and half… some restaurants had it on the table with salt and pepper, some poured it for us, then some we had to ask. When we asked for it some seemed fine giving it and we had like 1-2 that seemed a little annoyed. Not sure! But we definitely had an experience like that as well!

We don't put olive oil on bread in restaurants, but you can order bruschetta aglio e olio (which is with oil and garlic). Oil is brought to the table by default if you order a salad or some other dishes, but not for bread. However, in some restaurants in might be on the table already, but if you look around, you won't see Italians using it on their bread.
The olive oil and balsamic on the tables are not for dipping bread but to mix your salads with….
I've been in Italy for two months, waiters get extremly annoyed for everything, if you order ice, if you order oilive or balsamic etc. They are not very nice.

When I was a child, and even more so in the previous generations, a traditional "snack" for kids was bread with a little olive oil, salt, pepper, and depending on the tastes or the region also some anchovies. So putting olive oil on bread isn't something new in italian food culture. Of course, I wasn't there so I can't tell what happened, if you kind of "dipped" bread in oil that looks weird. You know what my guess is? They didn't feel like charging you for a little olive oil, so they were annoyed that it was going to be "wasted" like that. Olive oil costs nowadays, even the cheapest pne goes 6 euros per liter.
We don't make bruschette on the fly at restaurant lol
Because we Italians don't eat bread with oil in restaurants, we eat it by the "scarpetta" or while waiting for food, but without mixing it with anything else
Guess I will not ask for butter than lol
It might be the usual case of a waiter with poor English skills that doesn't know how to explain himself and so he just curtly dismisses the customer
They brought it with the bread at the restaurants we went to! 🤪 they even poured it for me adding the balsamic and salt &pepper at one place. So I don’t know…

If you pay to sit and eat in the restaurant ask for whatever you like. They will have attitude most of the time regardless of what you do because you are tourist. But without tourist they wouldn’t have jobs.

The people that haven’t had an issue are most likely frequenting restaurants that are used to dealing with tourists. Bread in general and especially dipping it in olive oil is not a thing in Italy. We have spent months through the years and tend to visit small towns or non tourist restaurants. Jmo
If costumer’s ask you for a EVO , just give it to him/her and STFK up .!
I’m from UK and would really like some butter with the bread 😎

From an Italian I suggest you order what you want and if you want a cappuccino with your meal or oil with your bread then you have it! If Italians don’t like it then maybe they would prefer tourists go elsewhere 🤷‍♀️ I am proud of my heritage but Italians can be very arrogant!

text:
Hello fellow Italy lovers 👋🏼 I have just booked last minute flights to Naples 31st July - 11th Aug. I am wanting to stay in Sorrento for the duration and do day trips for Amalfi, Positano and Capri.
I’m a solo traveller and struggling to get a decent priced accommodation for the duration of my stay. Can I please have recommendations on where’s the best places to stay but a cheap/reasonable price for a solo traveller ☺️ thank you!

Enjoying this FB page! Taking my mother (79 year old) and sister to Europe for their first time. Taking Norwegian cruise, it will be easier for my mother. We will be docked in Livorno for 2 days. We will visit Florence one day. Looking for recommendations for a reputable and reliable, with excellent reviews, private tour company for a day trip to visit small quaint villages and maybe a winery visit. Not using Norwegian excursion options for this stop. Appreciate any suggestions!

My friend’s daughter studied abroad and shared these recommendations for Florence and Rome (we are not going this trip but definitely saving this for when we do!). Thought I would share! 😊

Florence & Rome Recommendations
General Rules of Thumb:
• Gelato places that have huge mounds of gelato with fake fruit piled on top are going to be low quality, tourist traps! – search for silver tins/even some with lids, for more authentic gelato
• Restaurants with pictures of the food outside/on the menu are tourist traps – normally located around the big attractions, try to avoid if you can additionally, seek Osterias and Trattorias – ristorantes are usually not the best
• When eating outside, try to not leave your phone/wallet out on the table or sling your bag over the back of your chair – pickpockets are very savvy and will not be deterred that you’re sitting at a restaurant when it comes to getting their targets.
• Water is not free when you go out to eat, unlike here at home. Not an ungodly cost, but just factor that in whilst ordering! Specify still/flat water!
• Breakfast is not really a thing, maybe a pastry and espresso but do not expect omelets and pancakes at the hotel. Lunch is traditionally a smaller meal, check restaurant hours because lots will open for a small lunch window and close again before dinner. Dinner is late – 8/8:30ish.
• Florence - The grocery store is CONAD, there is one right next to the Duomo with a huge wine selection, meats and cheeses, snacks, etc. since you will be eating later – perhaps a glass of wine and a snack on the steps of some beautiful building will hold you over until dinner, open container law can be a wonderful thing

Florence
• Osteria Santo Spirito – truffle gnocchi and bruschetta is to die for, try to eat outside if you can, make a reservation!
• Simbiosi – pizza is not as common or as delicious as you are envisioning in Florence– however Simbiosi has the most delicious pizza of all. Beautiful restaurant, great wine menu, and fairly inexpensive.
• Panini Toscani – the only Piazza del Duomo recommendation – free samples, delicious, can still taste my order and miss it daily
• All’Antico Vinaio – paninis didn’t hit the spot for me the same way it hit the spot for everyone else… have amassed international fame though so they’re clearly doing something correctly
• Trattoria 13 Gobi – internationally recognized for their rigatoni dish, as they should be – also recommend the penne with steak and red wine sauce
• Acqua al Due – I have dreams about their blueberry steak, they have a steak sampler, pasta sampler, and a salad sampler – try it all!
• Quattro Leoni – pear and pecorino ravioli and cheesecake… ❤
• Il Mercato Centrale – Heaven on Earth. Basically, a food court with a bar in the middle – everyone can get what they want and try each other’s – from caprese salads to sushi, they also host cooking classes which could be a lot of fun!
• Trattoria Za Za – They have the entire breadth of Italian wants and menu needs – very well known for their Florentine steak! Make a reservation!
• La Giostra – if you want to have a more expensive, slightly more formal meal whilst you’re there, known for their steak. Ambiance is beautiful – make a reservation! Pics of famous people who have been there line the walls… worth it for a reason!
• La Buchetta – angels and demons gnocchi (basically alfredo sauce with a little spice)
• Gelateria del Neri – arguably the best gelato in all of Florence
• Don Nino and Edoardo’s – both in the Piazza del Duomo, loved by many – a little pricier because you’re paying for location, but still good
• La Carraia – inexpensive, lots of flavors, have two Florence locations
• Strega Nocciola – incredible, no notes for this gelato
• View on Art – never made it here myself, but rooftop bar with the perfect view of the Duomo
• Golden View – rather than a view of the duomo, there is a view of the Ponte Vecchio – seafood restaurant if you’re also looking for a carb break 😊
• Rosalia’s – it’s a lot of Italian food in not a lot of time, if you are craving a smoothie or something green, more delicious and fresher Panera
• Gusta Pizza – Diners, Drive Ins, and Dives traveled here – delicious, what you would hope Italian pizza to taste like! Check the hours before you go
• Il Profeta – expensive, however, out of this world. Owned by a husband and wife – the best thing is the chocolate cake
• Il Teatro – 20 euros for family style deliciousness – “unlimited wine”, a giant charcuterie platter that has these fried pasta dough balls that I dream of whenever I take a bite of bread, plus meats and cheese, and bruschetta. Then, three different pasta dishes that are rotating but could be pesto, alfredo, tortellini, etc. finally, there is a dessert platter with panna cotta, flan, cheesecake, and more. More casual if you wanted a more “let loose” evening.

Rome
• Osteria da Fortunata – an elderly woman sits in the window and hand makes the pasta… do you need any other reason to go there
• Taverna Trilussa – did not eat here myself, but heard amazing things – apparently expensive
• Giolitti – gelato and other delicious treats
• Old Bridge Gelateria – so many flavors of gelato
• Da Buffeto – best pizza in Rome
• Dar Poeta – also pizza, also the best

comments.comment_text: Agrigento

In short, Archeological sites of Temply Valley, Segesta Selinunte, Palermo (historical Norman architecture, Mondello beach and many other), Monreale, Trapani (nice town with a nice beaches), San Vito Lo Capo (beaches and amazing landscape) Erice (medieval village with stunning view), Castellammare del Golfo (loveable little town with nice beach), Scopello (beach), Zingaro Reserve (hiking in a natural park with stunning beaches), Marsala (beaches and amazing sunset at salt factory), Piazza Armerina (Villa del Casale), Syracuse (old town Ortigia), Ragusa (old town Ibla), Modica, Scicli, Noto, Scala dei Turchi (beautiful beach), Marzamemi (fishing village with loveable beach), Ventecane Reserve (hiking and nice beaches), Riviera Cyclops and their village (Acireale, Acitrezza, Acicastello), Catania, Etna Volcano, Taormina and Isolabella, Giardini Naxos (beaches), Cefalù (nice village and loveable beach).
Around Sicily there are many little Islands with fantastic sea and crystal water, one of them, Favignana, is at only an half hour from Trapani.
These are only some suggestions, there are so much to see the you can stay there a month and any day you have something of different to do.
Buy a good book guide and decide according your interests.
Rent a car, public transports there are not so good as mainland.
We fell in love with Taormina!

text: Anyone have experience with the Ferrari tours in Modena and Maranello? Adding in a trip to Lamborghini museum too? Suggestions on transportation between all 3. Starting point is Modena. Thank you!

comments.comment_text: F

We went to both Ferrari museums. it was a great experience and definitely worthwhile going to both. The one in Modena is a short walk from the city centre and is a bit like an art gallery but with actual cars suspended a little above the floor. Impressive! We walked there from our hotel. The next day we drove our rental car to Marinello. That museum is packed with beautiful road cars, race cars and engines from their early years to future concepts. You can also visit their racetrack! There's not much else in Marinello as the whole town seems to exist for manufacturing of Ferrari!

The Enzo museum in Modena is here he was born and the exhibition changes. In maranello you have the Ferrari museum with all the racing cars and history. You have a factory tour in a bus.
At Lamborghini you have the museum and a walking to the production line. It requires a reservation for the tour

text:
I’m traveling to Rome —> Florence —> Zurich —> Lucerne solo and have a few privacy concerns that I’m conflicted about

Would you recommend a backpack or rolling carry on? I ordered a calpak and love it, but it has a ton of zippers… got two TSA approved locks but would feel more comfortable with the one zipper / lock on my suitcase. I’m just worriedआणखी about the roads etc for the wheels.

Also, would you bring your passport with you and carry it in safely? A few of my hotels have safes, but one or two of my airbnbs don’t.

I assume I could leave a bag for a “back up plan” right?

Thank you!!

comments.comment_text: You can wear a money belt under your clothes when you go about at the airb&bs if you are worried. I have the same dilemma.

I prefer a backpack because I prefer to carry the weight with my core, not the end of my arms. It turns out I never had to leave it on a luggage rack, but I have a suitcase cover that fits around it (and could fasten straps around the rack) to make it difficult for anyone to unzip or grab and run.

Always carry your passport. There are many theft proof purse or bag options - wire mesh inside to prevent slashing, zippers lock, and look for one where the strap also locks/
unfastens so when you’re sitting you can fasten it to the chair, table leg, or whatever is convenient. When nothing else was available I just put the strap around one leg while I sat. I kept my passport, money, insurance cards, tickets, phone, and camera in mine (plus a few non-expensive but handy extras like hand sanitizer and water bottle), and didn’t have to worry about keeping an eye on the bag constantly.

Keep your passport on you. Wear a money belt at all times in public. Keep your money in it.Keep it inside your clothes just below your waist where it cannot be seen. I keep my passport in my money belt for safety.I put it in a plastic bag to keep it dry and clean.You will need to show it to the hotel reception desks where you are staying. Sometimes the police may ask to see your passport on the trains to identify yourself.
I travel a lot to Italy , my packback has a lot of zips and I like that as I also wear a crossbody bag , so I can keep all my important documents in🌻
Leave your passaport at the airbnb. Nobody will rob it.
Money Belt is a good idea

Switzerland rail provides some of the best train station services for people travelling with suitcases but the biggest problem with having a suitcase on wheels (that is heavy) is lugging it up staircases which you'll find lots of at old train stations and old buildings that don't have lifts.

I am in Lucerne right now after doing almost your exact itinerary. We have sturdy rolling bags (carry ons), back packs and I have a belt bag (worn crossbody). I have two locks, one on the main compartment of my suitcase and one on the main compartment of my backpack. I keep money in the belt bag and the passports in my backpack, locked compartment. A couple times I have put the passports in my belt bag. We have 7 train days. I also have leave them in the locked pack in our airbandbs. I do not take that backpack out with me during the day - I brought a smaller daypack and there’s nothing valuable in it. I brought money belts for all of us and haven’t used them once. You’ll figure out what your comfortable with. Have fun!
Take your passport with you . You will be fine…:))) Have 🤩
You will be fine..... Just don't make it easy for thieves..... Like some do. Places like Lucerne are very safe and friendly. ..... But expensive!! €33 for a pizza
Rhona OConnor

Passport must be on your person.
I prefer a small wheelie case these days. Light enough to carry if cobblestones become a problem.

text:
We will be flying into Rome Sept 11 at 8:45 AM. Our friends are not flying in until 3 PM. We will be meeting them back at the airport and going to Naples for a couple days at the start our vacation. ￼
Any suggestions what we can do while we are waiting about six hours for them? Anything close to the airport? We will have carry-on luggage. I don’t know if it is safe to leave it at the airport or we will be taking it with us for the day.
We’ll probably need lunch and a nap😄
Thank you

comments.comment_text: Go to Ostia Antica and check out the ruins or have lunch at the beach in Fiumicino.
We had to stay close to the airport and found a nice area right along Via della Torre Clementina on a canal. Lots of restaurants and bars. Decent walking area. Can’t advise about your bags.
The Hilton at the airport offers day rooms if you would like to nap and shower.

There is a spa very close to the Leonardo da Vincci airport, which might be an excellent way to unwind and start your vacation.

https://g.co/
kgs/2oK8u8 QC Termeroma
+39 02 8974 7209
Airport lockers. Train or taxi into the city. You probably won’t get in to see any of the sites like the Colosseum or Pantheon without tickets but you can walk around and see lots!
Can you get a locker for your bags at the airport?

Can you just meet them in Naples? Honestly seems a bit of a waste of your day to hang around the airport (assuming your flights and theirs get in on time and then allocate additional time for Customs). Otherwise might be easier to eat and shop in the airport. A taxi to Rome is at least a half hour, so you could go and have lunch and come back.
Thanks for all the input!

I don’t necessarily recommend doing an activity out in the sun right after getting off a long flight because you very well may be dehydrated. Your best bet is to read some restaurant reviews and find a spot in Ostia Antica. If you’re up to it, you can visit the ruins, but don’t plan on pushing yourselves too hard on day one. Also, there are luggage lockers at FCO airport that you should be able to utilize.
Sleep

The little town of Fiumicino is just a brief cab ride away - there is a specific cab rank opposite the airport and it’s simple and cheap to check your bags at the airport left luggage office. It’s a charming fishing village where the Tiber meets the sea and it’s a nice place to wander around and there are many quaint restaurants where you could have a nice leisurely lunch. You can also ask the cab driver that took you there to return at a certain time.

At Rome Airport there is luggage storage located in the International Arrivals of Terminal 3. I agree with suggestion to go into Fiumicino. The riverfront area has many little restaurants, and it won't be crowded. You might not have a lot of time to do much else.
QC Termeroma Go to this day spa… get a massage and enjoy their Roman baths, they have an airport shuttle and is 10 minutes away from the FCO.
Meet them at Naples. Is riding a train together really THAT important?

Visit ideas :
Duomo, navigli, Cenacolo, botanical garden, galleria VE II, castello Sforzesco, art nouveau, street art porta Ticinese, basilica San Lorenzo, rooftop bar at Rinascente with view on the Duomo, make sure to book well in advance for the Cenacolo.
Armani Hotel in Via Manzoni.

On recent trip, totally enjoyed staying city center, you will be immersed in all the holiday decor, shopping & outside events. All walking, all easily accessible. Location was optimal. Yes, more pricey, no need for car, parking, never needed a taxi,
Hotel Berna near the train station. A 25 min walk to the Duomo
City center, definitely!
Stay in the city center. December is cold and foggy in Milano. Take day trips to Switzerland!
